Dear ##SM_RULE_360 Email Salutation##,

The Oregon District Attorneys Association (ODAA) has been caught in another troubling controversy.

The ODAA is the political arm and coordinating organization for Oregon's 36 district attorneys, and it recently held its summer conference in Bend. The surprising element of the conference was who they invited to be the keynote speaker: Bob McCulloch, the outgoing chief prosecutor for St. Louis County.

Email the District Attorney Association’s president and to make it clear that they have crossed a line.

Bob McCulloch made national news when he refused to prosecute the police officer who shot and killed Michael Brown in Ferguson in 2014. But McCulloch's reputation is broader and uglier than the Michael Brown case. For almost 30 years, he was the chief prosecutor in a county known for extreme racial disparity and discrimination. That's why voters kicked him out of office just last month.

Given McCulloch's history, it is no surprise his presentation in Oregon was racially charged and offensive. Several prosecutors walked out and Willamette Week reported that McCulloch not only mocked the ACLU and other criminal justice reform groups but also reinforced racist stereotypes of Black men as criminals.

So what was the Oregon District Attorneys Association hoping to learn from a guest speaker with a long legacy of racially discriminatory practices? We should expect better from our law enforcement leaders.

Tell the DA Association bigotry is not an Oregon value.

Sincerely,

david rogers
Executive Director
ACLU of Oregon
